div.p: 1. IV:30. Sun rose 5:7. Walk to Georgetown—

Governor Barbour called, having just returned from his visit to Virginia. We had some conversation upon several subjects in the business of the War Department, during his absence— The order from the Engineer Department of 17. August 1826. introducing several new, and highly important regulations, at the Military Academy at West Point, and which has given rise to several difficult questions, was adopted in my absence last Summer, and never even communicated to me. I have doubts of its legality on several points, besides that upon which the Officers appointed by the Superintendent for a Court of Enquiry refused to act— I learnt from Governor Barbour that the real object of the order was to limit the punishments to which the Cadets should be liable, exclusively to the penalties enumerated in the Order— And he said the order was issued at the solicitation of Coll Thayer himself— One consequence of this has been that several of the Sentences of this Court Martial, must be disapproved as not included in the list of enumerated penalties, and thus the offenders will escape punishment altogether, or the sentences must be approved to the disregard of the order itself— Governor Barbour thought that such punishments as suspension from the Academy or from pay and emoluments, were objectionable in principle, as they took from the Cadet the benefit of education, for which he is there, and he thought degradation from rank might be inflicted by the Superintendent at his Discretion, it being the mere withdrawal of a distinction granted at his discretion— But the Articles of War give in many cases an indefinite and discretionary power to Courts Martial to inflict any punishment they think proper, and an Act of Congress declares that the Cadets shall be subject to the Articles of War— My question then is whether a mere Executive Order can prescribe to Courts Martial, a very small list of penalties, as the only ones to which they shall sentence Cadets, and thereby restrict the indefinite power given them by the Articles of War— Governor Barbour said he would submit the question to the Attorney General, for his opinion: and would suggest to Coll. Thayer the propriety of a revisal of the order of 17. August 1826. Messrs.Thomas, Hoffman and Macaulay are a Committee on behalf of the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-road Company, to ascertain how far and upon what terms the assistance of the general Government can be obtained in furnishing detachments from the Topographical Engineers to make the necessary surveys of the route of the proposed road— They first wrote me a Letter, announcing their appointment and its object, and called upon me at one. I assured them of my earnest good wishes for the success of their undertaking, and of my disposition to give them every aid in the power of the Executive Government to bestow—referring them for particulars to the Secretary of War, who I informed them was now in the City, and with whom I advised them to confer. Mr Mercer the member of Congress from Loudon County afterwards called on me: deeply anxious for the fate of his projected Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which he yet flatters himself will not be defeated by this Railway: though the two undertakings must interfere with each other— I congratulated Mercer upon his re-election to Congress: and he declared himself gratified with the re-election of Mr Newton, and mortified at the failure of Mr Powell— Commodore Chauncey called; being on his way from New-York to accompany the Commissioners of the Navy to Norfolk, to make arrangements for commencing the work of a dry Dock at that place— Mr Rush brought me a Statement of the revenue received at the Treasury, for the first Quarter of this year, so far as the returns have come in— It upwards of five Millions and a half, about 230000 dollars less than the corresponding Quarter of the last year. The falling off is less than he had recently anticipated, but promises a Million less for the Revenue of the whole year than we had estimated at the close of the last year— I spoke to Mr Rush of measures for obtaining information, political and commercial from the British Colonies, at the North of this Continent, and in the West-Indies— I had some days since spoken to Mr Clay on the same Subject; but there is some difficulty in making the arrangement— John dined at Commodore Bainbridge’s— The weather which for the first fortnight of April had been nearly at Summer heat, has during the last ten days been bleak and cold— This day there was Snow— The fireside was indispensable.
2. V. Sun rose cloud-veiled— Walk to College Hill—

Dr Wallace, the eccentric physician paid me a long visit, having come yesterday from his residence in Fauquier County, Virginia— He brought with him as usual a specimen of natural history—a dead Spanish fly of the Cantharides kind, packed in cotton in a pill box. He sent me sometime since the quill of a Condor. There is a wildness about the Doctor’s imagination, perhaps akin to genius— Mr Rush called while he was here; with another case for remission of a forfeiture of a British vessel from the West-Indies, arrived since the proclamation was issued. The question was whether after the remission, the vessel could be permitted to take a cargo— Mr Rush had answered that she might—clearing out for an open Port, and giving bonds to proceed accordingly— Dr. May and Mr Law, came as a Committee from the Washington Canal company, to request my approbation of the plan of a basin on the Canal, which approbation is made necessary by an Act of Congress of 20. May 1826. They had a plan of the Canal, with the Basin as contemplated, laid down upon it; without note of its dimensions; but I thought the Law required that there should be a plan of the Basin itself marking its length and breadth—upon which my approbation should be entered; and subscribed by me— They said would procure and bring me such a plan— Mr D. Brent came for the Letter from Governor Lincoln of Maine, which Mr Clay is to answer— I advised that the copies of Papers requested by him should be furnished— I also asked Mr Brent to send me the Volumes of my fathers despatches to Congress, when he was Minister in England; and Mr Jefferson’s Report upon Commerce in 1793— Mr William Lee came and took away his two Spanish books on the Cultivation of the Vine— Mr Baker the Clergyman, paid me the second of his four annual notes, which was this day payable— Spoke of the Clerks dismissed from the general Land-Office, recommended specially Joseph Wheaton, and exhorted me very urgently to secure the Salvation of my own Soul, by conversion and regeneration— Rufus King died last Sunday. 29. April. Aged 72.
3. V.5— Sun rising— Walk round Tyber and Potowmac bridge Square.

Mr Rush called, and shewed me a Letter from Mr Monroe to C. J. Ingersoll, in answer to one he had written him, upon the result of the trial of the libel suit of L. Harris against W. D. Lewis. Mr Monroe speaks also in the same Letter of his own pecuniary embarrassments, and acknowledges himself to have been under some obligations to Ingersoll in reference to them— Ingersoll had sent the Letter to Mr Rush with a request that it might be returned to him, and Mr Rush said he supposed Ingersoll wished it might be shewn to me— Ingersoll says also he believes we shall gain the tea causes— Mr Rush received afterwards and sent me a Letter from Mr Wirt, expressing the same expectation— But I do not believe we shall— My experience for many years upon the result of trials at Law is we have no practical judicial remedy for the public against fraud— The tea-cheaters will escape as the Bank-cheaters have escaped— Mr John Myers of Norfolk was here: son of my old acquaintance Moses Myers who called upon me last Sunday— Moses Myers is a Candidate for the appointment of Collector at Norfolk, though neither he nor his Son, spoke of that to me. Mr Rush to whom the son has applied said much of it, and there are great difficulties in the way— Mr Clay was here and spoke of the Letter from Governor Enoch Lincoln of Maine that he is to answer— He said he felt some repugnance at furnishing the copies of the papers which he unreasonably requires. I thought as there was little prospect of success to the negotiation, the furnishing of copies could not prove injurious— Mr Clay said he would prepare a draught of a Letter, for consideration— He mentioned also the claims of our Citizens upon the French Government, and thought it would be necessary to give some fresh Instruction to Mr Brown, though he expected no success unless we would allow them some indemnity upon their Louisiana Convention claim— I said I could not well agree to that. He will however prepare an Instruction to Mr Brown— Mrs Adams had company this Evening, but I did not see them—
4. IV:45. Sun rose 5:4. North one disk, of State Dept. Chimneys— Round Capitol Square

The Postmaster General M’lean introduced Mr Hind and Mr Southgateb. Hind is from Kentucky, and spoke with great regard of my old Classmate Daniel Mayo, with whom he is intimately acquainted— Tyler has been rambling about in Pennsylvania, and Maryland, since he was last here, and had much political conversation, at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania; where he was, at the time when the Legislature of that State adjourned— Mr Ord is a Justice of Peace, and came to take my Oath to an Answer in Chancery to a Bill of James Corcoran—but I was not ready and he promised to call again to-morrow— General Parker came in behalf of a Coll. Thomas, who has a suit of the United States against him in the U.S. Circuit Court at New-York— But Tillotson the District Attorney has not entered it upon the Docket. I received yesterday a Letter from Thomas complaining of this, and asking an order from me to Tillotson to Docket the action— I referred Parker to Mr Pleasonton the agent of the Treasury for the prosecution of all such suits— He also spoke to me of a claim which he himself has, for a commutation of fuel and quarters in lieu of double rations— He brings this claim up, under a new form, upon which he wishes me to decide, and left a paper with me for that purpose. Mr Mercer introduced Mr Bronson, a young man from New-York— Governor Barbour brought papers of Lieutenant Alberti, and took those which Alberti sent me; containing charges against Lieutenant Beckley, Paymaster Massias, and Surgeon Weightman, and bitter complaints against Genl. Scott and Genl. Brown— The Charges against the three subordinate Officers are of a grave character, and the witnesses are all named— I could not perceive why the Court of enquiry claimed by Lieutt. Alberti had been refused— The Governor spoke also of the fray between Lieutt. Wheelock and Greene at West-Point, wherein Green received corporal chastisement— He declined appearing before an informal Court of Enquiry; and is now here demanding an Official one— There is a Lady in the case, Wheelock’s wife, and he is therefore exceedingly averse to a Court of Enquiry which would make the Affair public— We are to consider the matter further. I decided yesterday on the nineteen Sentences of the Court-Martial, upon the Cadets tried for riots last Christmas day—and sent the decisions with a short paper of general remarks on the whole case, to the War Department— Miss Roberdeau left us again this evening—
5. V:10. Sun risen clear at 5.3.— Walk to College Hill.

Mr Anderson the Comptroller of the Treasury, introduced his eldest Son, and a young man named Patrick, from the State of Alabama, who has been at Winchester, Virginia, attending the Law School of Henry StGeorge Tucker— Handy is a Clerk in one of the Public Offices, and brought me several very respectable recommendations from Governor Kent of Maryland, and others: Mr Handy has a large family with slender means of supporting them; and wishes to provide for two of his Sons, by a warrant of Cadet at West-Point, for one of them, and a Midshipman’s warrant for the other. Mr Rush brought a draught of a Letter to Dr Mease upon the subject of enquiries relating to the natural History and Cultivation of useful foreign Plants, which might be advantageously introduced into this Country. This is a subject which will require long and persevering attention; and a systematic pursuit, the issue of which after all must be doubtful— Mr Rush had already made some enquiries at Canton in China—not concerning foreign plants, but of varieties of those which we have as garden vegetables and fruits, and particularly the Cotton Plant— He read me an answer received from Canton, and one from Calcutta; neither of which is encouraging— They State that all the fruits and garden plants in use there are far inferior to the same kind of vegetables in Europe— But Canton is on the tropic and Calcutta nearly so: and could not be expected to produce fruits
to thrive in our Northern Climates— Mr Ord came and administered to me, the Oath, upon my answer to the Bill in Chancery of James Corcoran— He also took my acknowledgment of a Power to my Son George to receive dividends on Massachusetts Fire and Marine Insurance Company Stock, which Power I received this morning from George to be executed— Mr Clay and Mr Southard were here together— Clay had an insolent Letter from a man at Ithaca, New-York named Stockholm who three or four years since wrote me several Letters professing to be an ardent partizan of my election to the President, and wanted an Office— He now complains that I neglect and sacrifice my friends, and thinks General Jackson’s qualifications and prospects for the Presidency greatly improved— Mr Clay mentioned his wish to go to Kentucky at the close of this Month, to return here in July; and to be absent again a few weeks in August and September. Mr Southard had a Letter from Commodore Hull, declining to accept the appointment of a Commissioner of the Navy and asking for a furlough— Mr Southard thought he could be persuaded to accept the Office of Commissioner, which I somewhat doubted— We had much conversation concerning the appointment of a Collector of Norfolk—in which there is great difficulty.
6. V. Sun rose 5:2.

Heard Mr Little, from 1. John. 2.15. “Love not the world, nor the things that are in the world.” The comment upon this text is more appropriate to other Sects of Christianity than to that which Mr Little sustains—enjoyment of the world, in the practice of virtue is congenial to the unitarian doctrine— Use the world as not abusing it, is the precept of that faith— After a visit from General Wool just returned from attending a Court of Enquiry at Harper’s Ferry, I heard Mr Campbell at Mr Baker’s— His text was from Revelation 2:16. “Repent or else I will come unto thee quickly.” Mr Campbell, dwelt largely and earnestly upon the universal depravity of mankind— It is matter of curious speculation to me, how men of good understanding and reasoning faculties can be drilled into the sincere belief of these absurdities— The Scripture says that the heart is deceitful above all things and desperately wicked—this is certainly true; and is a profound observation upon the human character. But the language is figurative—by the heart, is meant in this passage the selfish passions of man— But there is also in man a Spirit, and the inspiration of the almighty giveth him understanding— It is the duty of man to discover, and controul the vicious propensities, and deceits of his heart to controul them— This with the grace of God, a large portion of the human race in Christian Lands to a considerable extent do accomplish. It seems therefore to be worse than useless for preachers to declare that mankind are universally depraved. It takes from honest integrity all its honours—it degrades men in their own estimation— Mr Campbell read a hymn, which declared that we were more base and brutish than the beasts—a spiritual Song of Isaac Watts’—what is the meaning of this?— If Watts had said this on a week day to any one of his parishioners, would he not have knocked him down? And how can that be taught as a solemn truth of religion, applicable to all mankind, which if said at any other time to any one individual would be punishable as Slander. Heard Mr Little again in the Evening—from Jeremiah 3.15. “And I will give you pastors according to mine heart, which shall feed you with knowledge and Understanding.” He made some remarks upon the peculiar character of the Jewish Nation, and of this Book the Bible; much of it written a thousand years before the arts of civilization had made any progress in other Nations since so distinguished in the world: and in commenting upon the gift of pastors, who should feed the people with knowledge and understanding he spoke with great severity of those, who administer food of another description; lying legends of Saints, or the reveries of bewildered imaginations— Miracles never performed, and persons who never existed, visions and dreams; pretended intercourse, and personal communications with Jesus Christ, and experiences of fancied conversion and regeneration— Johnson Hellen who was with me, thought this vituperation of the Roman Catholics and Methodists too severe— After returning home I took up my papers relating to the question of the Colonial trade with Great-Britain; but there is so much to read upon the subject, that the Evening was wasted before I could write a line—
7— V:5. Potowmac Bath— Rain.

I had sent on Saturday to Mr Elgar, requesting him to call here, and he came this morning. I remonstrated against the cutting down of trees in the enclosure between the house and the river—two of these trees were cut down, Saturday morning before I was aware what they were doing— Elgar said that was necessary for their plan of levelling the grounds; but that they did not propose to cut down any more— Mr Anderson the Comptroller came as I had requested of him on Saturday— I read to him the draught of the Letter I had written to him and Mr Pleasonton, concerning the Settlement of my accounts as a Minister abroad— He said they would readily answer it. He sat with me nearly two hours conversing upon politics and persons—and gave me particularly an account of his own relations with H. L. White now a Senator from Tennessee— He spoke also of L. W. Tazewell, the Senator from Virginia; both now bitter and inveterate political and personal enemies to me— Dr Todsen came to solicit my influence in his favour, to obtain the appointment of a Clerk in the Department of State, vacated by the decease this morning of George E. Ironside— It was the first notice I had of his death— I had placed him in the year 1820 in the Department of State, and he was one of the most valuable Officers in the Public Service— I deeply regret the loss of him— I told Dr Todsen that the appointment of a Clerk, belonged by Law exclusively to the head of the Department. That I could not interfere, unless Mr Clay should consult me, in which case I would say nothing to his disadvantage. Mr Clay afterwards called, and told me he had concluded to advance Mr Slade to the station which had been occupied by Mr Ironside, and to appoint George Watkins, a Son of the Doctor, to the vacant Clerkship; which I fully approved. Mr Clay left with me two private Letters to him—one from C. Hammond, at Cincinnati: and the other from W. B. Rochester at Mexico— Mr Clay mentioned to me also that Dr Kent had sent him a Letter from Henry R. Warfield, complaining that he had not received an Appointment— That I had not answered his Letters of Solicitation— That he had applied to be a Commissioner under the new Slave Convention; that enemies to the Administration had been appointed in his stead; and that he must have an Office— Dr Watkins came to shew me a Letter from J. Barney of Baltimore, complaining somewhat in the same Style, that he could not obtain a West-Point Cadet’s Warrant for his Son. I had a Letter to the same effect from Barney himself. Mr Rush had two Letters from C. J. Ingersoll; one giving notice that the verdict and decision in the U.S. Circuit Court at Philadelphia, in the Thompson Tea Cases, was against the United States. And the other that Mr Wirt and he had concluded not to commence the Prosecutions in the State Courts which they had recommended— This day was again so cold that I had fire again in my writing chamber— I did nevertheless bathe in the River— John attended a Meeting of the Directors of the Franklin Fire Insurance Company, and did not dine at home. I took Charcoal—
8. IV:45— Sun rose at 5. Walk to Potowmac rock

The weather was too cold, and the wind too strong for a bath— Evans was a man from New-Hampshire, deaf and dumb, but who conversed with me sometime by writing upon a Slate— He came to see me from mere curiosity— Robinson came to renew his solicitation for an office— Governor Barbour brought me a Letter to him from Mr. Cobb, the Senator from Georgia in behalf of young Campbell, a Cadet at West-Point— He was a witness first on the Court of Enquiry, and afterwards at the Court-Martial upon the trial of Berrien; and his testimony as to very important facts was directly and positively self-contradictory. The Court recommended that he should be dismissed from the Service of the United States for gross prevarication— I had suspended the decision in that case, with the intention of finally permitting him to remain; in consideration of his youth and inexperience— Governor Barbour had also a Letter from John Barney, the member from Baltimore, urging the admission of his Son, as a Cadet at West-Point— I mentioned to him the application of Mrs Sumter, for her Son— Mr Knapp introduced his two acquaintances Mr Walker of Boston, and Mr Cornish of Philadelphia as visitors— Mr Bussard
came to ask an answer to a Petition he had addressed to me some weeks since, about a debt owed by him to the Bank of the United States and to the United States; transferred from the Bank of Columbia. His proposal is to pay this debt by gun powder, of which he has a manufactory, and to be furnished by him, by contracts with the War and Navy Departments— I referred him to the Secretaries; and he is to call to-morrow for his petition— Mr Clay and Mr Rush called together— Clay with Letters from P. B. PorterMr Hawkins of Baltimore and James Thomas at Philadelphia— All upon topics of the times— Mr Rush had a petition from New-Orleans, for a grant of a lot of Land, bordering upon the Custom-house in that City, to build upon it a Church for the Sailors— It is at least questionable whether the Executive power is competent to grant the land, without an Act of Congress—but Mr Rush will write to the Collector at New-Orleans to ascertain whether the land can without inconvenience be spared— The leisure of this day was anxiously occupied upon the British Colonial trade subject.
9. IV:50.— Sun rose. 4:59. Potowmac River cold bath.

Long was an Inspector of the Customs at Elizabeth City, North-Carolina; he told me that he had come up in the Steam-boat, to appeal against his dismission, by the new Collector, Rogerson—said he had been twenty seven years in the Office under the former Collector Sawyer—had a wife and a large family of children to maintain, and no other means of support— He was a friend of the Administration, and the Collector was much otherwise— I referred him to the Secretary of the Treasury, to know the charges against him, and assured him that he should not suffer injustice— He went to the Treasury, and afterwards came back saying they had got up dreadful charges against him; but he should immediately return home, and send here a full refutation of them— They were habitual intoxication, and discredit so that a judge had declared he was not to be believed in a Court of Justice— Mr Rush fears that he will not be able to work out a good deliverance— Mr Barrell came to solicit an appointment in behalf of John Otis, a person in whose favour, I have a memorial from certain inhabitants of Barnstable, Massachusetts. He also urged the claim of William Otis, brother of John, and formerly Collector of Barnstable, now a Clerk in the general Land-Office— He was Collector, during the embargo and was ruined as he alledges by judgments obtained against him for seizures under the embargo Laws. But he was dismissed for retaining monies received as Collector, which he has since paid— He wrote me some days since, requesting a personal investigation by me of the charges against him; and the opportunity to defend himself— I told Mr Barrell, that I would examine the subject as well as I could; but that Mr Otis must go to Congress for the Settlement of his claim— Mr Bussard came and took away his petition, and Mr D. Brent with Letters, requesting information of the appointments I have held under the Government of the United States: General Washington’s Letter to my father concerning me, and my Letter of resignation, as a member of the U.S. Senate. I told him where this information could be found; and asked him for the Annual Register of 1783. and the Acts of Parliament of 1796. both of which he sent me, but they did not contain the information that I wanted. Dr Todsen came and delivered to me a Letter from Mr Humphrey in his favour which I told him I would put on file. Atkinson and Campbell are two young men, from Chancellor Tucker’s Law School at Winchester who came on a visit of curiosity— W. Lee came and took away his two volumes of Chaptal upon the cultivation of the Vine; and Mr Rush came to ask for the papers of the investigation by the U.S. District Attorney of Maine, of the complaints against the disorders in the Custom House at Castine— The Collector Josiah Hook, is since deceased— We had a small company to dine— Mr Rush and his mother— Mr Southard— Mrs Cooper; late Maria Mason— Mr R. Cutts. W. Lee Columbus Munroe, with his mother and Sister. Dr. and Mrs Watkins and Aaron Vail— Mrs R. Rush, Mrs. Southard— Mrs General Brown, with Mr and Mrs Brockenbrough— Mrs Cutts— Mr T. Munroe, young Bouligny and George Watkins were invited but sent excuses—
10. V:15. Cloudy— Potowmac bath— Rain.

The early morning was mild, and I bathed in the Potowmac, as I had yesterday and Monday, with a view to bring out the inflammation with which I have been for weeks suffering internally—and I have apparently succeeded; but with a prospect of increased complaint for the approaching Summer— I had scarcely returned from the excursion of the morning when it began to rain, and it fell copiously three or four hours— Cleared away in the Evening— Mr Southard brought and read me Letters received from Captain Woolsey at Pensacola; from Captain Biddle on the Coast of Brazil, and from Commodore Rodgers at Malta— Woolsey in a private Letter complains that Captain David Porter, now in the Mexican Service, and having taken refuge in a Frigate at Key-West, is using that place as a station of annoyance to the Spanish Commerce, and abusing its neutrality obviously for the purpose of making misunderstanding between the United States and Spain. Biddle was in correspondence with Brazilian blockading Officers: and Rodgers who had before reported sickness in the Squadron, now announces health as generally prevailing— I spoke to Mr Southard of my desire to obtain information of the natural history and cultivation of foreign plants, fruits and forest trees, of special usefulness with a view to introduce the cultivation of them into this Country: and suggested the expediency of a circular Letter of Instruction to the Captains of our Public Ships who visit distant parts of the world, to lend their assistance in co-operation with the Consuls to effect that object— He said he would be thinking of it; and would converse with Mr Rush concerning it— Mr Rush called and gave me Letters recommendatory of Moses Myers, from Mr Madison, and from Judge Washington— Mr Connell from Philadelphia came and spent surely two hours of the Evening with me— He is going to Copenhagen, as Agent for certain Claimants upon the Danish Government, and wishes some documentary assistance from us. Mr Henry Wheaton, is going there shortly as Chargé d’Affaires.
11. IV:45— Sun rose 4:57. Walk round Capitol Square.

I lose my Confidence both in morning baths and walks for the preservation of my health— But what shall take their place?— Mr Graham came with a proclamation to be signed for the sale of Lands in Missouri— He had also an answer from the Register, at the Office where an erroneous Patent issued— The man to whom it was issued has sold the Land, and answers with insolence the demand to deliver up his Patent: the Register has published a Notification that the Patent was erroneously issued; and Mr Graham will consult the Attorney General with regard to further proceedings. Mr Southard came with a voluminous bundle of papers— Proceedings of the Court of Enquiry, on the complaints of Captain Kuhn, against Coll. Henderson and Lieutenant Hall— He had not read them; and proposed postponing the discharge of the Court, till he should have examined the report, to which I agreed. He thought no further measures would be necessary against Coll Henderson, but that Hall must probably be tried by a Court Martial— Governor Barbour called; somewhat anxious concerning the appointment of a Collector at Norfolk, and in favour of Moses Myers— Edward Wyer came with much nothingness to tell. There is an interlude of Moliere’s, called Les Fâcheux. We have no synonimous term in our language— Mr Clay spoke of despatches received from Condy Raguet, who was Chargé d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro, but who has quarrelled with the Government there and demanded his Passports which have been furnished him, and he is coming home— He appears to have been too hasty in his proceedings, and has made us much trouble, from which we can derive neither credit nor profit— I returned to Mr Clay the private Letters that he had lent me from General Porter and others. Captain Hitchcock came to explain to me the grounds upon which he and two other Officers, appointed by Coll. Thayer as a Court of Enquiry at West-Point had refused to act— They considered the Court as illegally convened; it being only by Order of the Superintendent, the 92d. Article of War vesting in the President alone the power of ordering Courts of Enquiry, unless demanded by the accused— The Attorney General and the Secretary of War thought that constructively the order from the War Department was an order from the President, and that an order by a
general regulation was equivalent to a special order in each separate case— He said that notwithstanding this opinion of the Secretary of War and Attorney General, the Court persisted in the opinion that they were not legally convened, and still declined proceeding: in consequence of which they had first been put under arrest and then ordered to join their regiments— He said he was desirous the question might be fully considered, that others might avoid the same inconvenience, and that of all the Officers at the Point there was only one who doubted the illegality of the order— I told him that I had the subject under deliberate consideration— Mrs Mills is a Sister of a wretched man named De Vaughn under Sentence of Death at Alexandria, for an atrocious murder— She came in a state of extreme agitation and distress, to solicit a commutation of his punishment— Her tears and sobs and supplications deeply affected me— Her Story told in untutored language was itself moving— I scarcely dare think of it— I was immeasurably tempted to say something to her which would have given her a hope that he might be pardoned—yet I felt that I ought not— There is nothing to palliate the crime; and almost every thing to excite sympathy for his suffering— She says he is 78 years of age—one of a family of ten brothers and Sisters; all in respectable Stations of life—almost all with families of children— He himself has an estimable wife and many children— More than a hundred persons, relatives as brothers Sisters and their descendants will suffer torture by his Execution— One Sister has taken to her bed and she is sure will die— She herself since his sentence has not had day or night a moment’s peace of mind— His head is white as Snow— Heavy with age— It is but a short time that could be given him—and must he die—must he be hung?— All this and more I heard, and while it wrung my heart, I resisted every impulse to comfort her with hope— I listened kindly to all she had to say, and told her, that my duty was of the most painful kind— That I felt deeply for her distress and that of her relatives; but that I could not talk with her on the matter of which she spoke. That it would have been extremely grateful to me, if I could have afforded her relief, but it was not in my power— Mr Lee came in, and she left me with thanks for the kindness I had shewn her— Lee’s object was to read me a letter from Elijah H. Mills, who is yet at Philadelphia, and says he is better, and who wishes for employment on a foreign mission, where he may go and recover— This case appeals also to sympathies of life and death— Mr Rush called with a proposition to ascertain if Moses Myers could not pay off the balance of his dues on Custom House Bonds, upon being assured that he might then depend on receiving the appointment of Collector at Norfolk— J. Connell was here this evening; and took leave; going to-morrow on his return to Philadelphia—
12. IV:50— Sun rose 4:56— Walk round Tiber Squares.

Mr Anderson the Comptroller introduced to me a young man named Wright, of North-Carolina, who has been attending Chancellor Tuckers Law Lectures at Winchester— Mr. Anderson requested me also to have returned to him his Letter; recommending Tunstall to be Collector at Norfolk. He said that since sending it to me, he had heard Tunstall was unfriendly to the Administration, and he would recommend no such person to any Office. Mr Van Buren paid me a morning visit: he is on his return from a tour through Virginia, North and South-Carolina, and Georgia, with C. C. Cambreleng, since the close of the Session of Congress. They are generally understood to have been electioneering, and Van Buren is now the great electioneering manager for General Jackson as he was before the last Election for Mr Crawford— He is now acting over the part in the affairs of the Union, which Aaron Burr performed in 1799 and 1800. and there is much resemblance of character, manners and even person between the two men— Van Buren however has improved as much in the art of electioneering upon Burr, as the State of New-York has grown in relative strength and importance in the Union. Van Buren has now every prospect of success in his present movements, and he will avoid the rock upon which Burr afterwards split— His discourse
with me this day was upon the late Mr Rufus King, his History and Character, and upon Mr Monroe and his Affairs— Also upon the Petersburg Horse-races which he has been attending— He proceeds on his journey homeward to-morrow, and on Mr Rush’s coming in took leave. Mr Rush is still occupied with this appointment of a Collector at Norfolk; and has taken measures to ascertain if Mr Myers can pay off the balance due from him upon Custom-house Bonds— Mr Mower of the New-York Post-Office was here, and very prudently reserved in his talk upon politics— I desired him to congratulate from me General Bailey, the Postmaster at New-York, and to assure him that I hoped his health would continue, and enable him to retain his office at least, during my time— Mr Clay brought the Correspondence of Mr Condy Raguet, with the Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs, which terminated in his demanding and obtaining his Passports. We concurred in the opinion that Raguet could not be sustained in this proceeding, and his conduct there has long been deficient in temper and discretion— Mr Clay thinks it will be advisable to appoint a Minister Plenipotentiary to Brazil, with a view to the Negotiation of a Treaty of Commerce; I incline to the same opinion, but believe it will be necessary to reflect upon the subject, and to prepare for a nomination to the Senate, at their next Session— Mr Southard informed me that he had discharged the Court of Enquiry on the charges against Henderson and Hall—Coll. Gamble, President of the Court having received a summons to attend a sick child. Southard had a Letter from J. Wurtz at Philadelphia, mentioning that he had been urged to stand as a Candidate for Congress in the vacancy occasioned by an equal vote between J. Sergeant and Horn. Southard asked if Sergeant would be back and again a Candidate— I presumed he would, as there was no prospect of the meeting of the Congress at Tacubaya— Southard spoke of Commodore Hull, who is or in a day or two will be here— Of Lieutenant Percival, yet in prison at New-York—of Commodore Bainbridge just returned from the Survey at Norfolk, and of J. C. Jones junr Consul at the Sandwich Islands, of whom he had received unfavourable reports— We had Letters from George, who has been elected Captain of the City Guards and was a Candidate for re-election to the Legislature— The election was on Thursday the tenth; but they are in such a political Chaos at Boston, that the issue is exceedingly doubtful— Mr Clay had also a Letter from Mr Webster; concerning the Senatorial Election; from which he thinks he cannot escape.
13. IV.55. Precisely at Sun rise.

Heard at Mr Little’s a young man, named Emerson, from 1. Thessalonians 5:17. “Pray without ceasing” good composition—dull and dronish delivery— Afternoon at Mr Baker’s. Heard Mr of Alexandria from John 3.16. “For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life”— This person’s manner is pleasing to me, because there is great sincerity in its vehemence— He entangled himself in some doctrine of the peculiar mode of filiation of Jesus Christ— It seemed as if he was anxious to extricate the creed of the Trinity, from one of its most flagrant absurdities, as it shews itself to human reason— His argument was that Christ was God— That he was also the Son of God— But not as God— His filiation or Sonship was confined to his incarnate state— But the idea to be annexed to the terms father and Son, as applied to God, he attempted not, nor will any Trinitarian ever attempt to define— I thought the discourse was chiefly preached for my special benefit, but it was wheat sown by the way side. The divinity of Christ was mentioned as indispensable to sustain the atonement, and without the atonement there was no way of Salvation— I had already often heard this before; and lately in private conference with Mr Baker— I understand it however, none the better— In the Evening Johnson Hellen went with me to Mr Little’s—we heard him from John 4.14. “But whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst; but the water that I shall give him, shall be in him a well of water springing up into everlasting life.” a discourse upon the excellency of the Christian morality— I answered a Letter yesterday received from my Son George— It is difficult to sustain my hopes of his prosperity— My own health is yet drooping— The inflammation with which I suffered so much last Summer returns with increased severity— If wishing could end it, my complaints would soon be relieved, but I must await my allotted time— My own Career is closed— My hopes such as are left me, are centered upon my children. George’s state is precarious; and his prospects are doubtful— My capacity to write, fails me from day to day— My duties are to prepare for the end, with a grateful heart, and unwavering mind—
14. IV:50— Sun rose 4:54. Walk to College Hill

Mr Reigart is a Citizen of Pennsylvania, from Lancaster County, who came to pay a visit of curiosity— The Comptroller Anderson, introduced his namesake who like himself was an Officer during the War of the Revolution— The Coll. served and was wounded in the South-Carolina campaigns— His Son was with them and is a physician usually residing in South-Carolina; a neighbour of General Sumter, and of his Son— Mr Rush, was twice here—first with a Letter commendatory of M. Myers, from L. Cheves, and afterwards with papers relating to the Seizure of a vessel called the Camillus from Glasgow; for bringing an excess of Passengers— Lee came as an Agent for the owners, upon this application and Fyfe was a Cabin passenger in the vessel. The English Law, allows three children under six and two, under thirteen years of age to be counted for one— Our Law counts every individual; and as there were fifty children passengers in this vessel, she was within the limits of the British-Law, but transcended ours— Lee and Fyfe were here, and Lee brought a Letter of strong recommendation from Charles King. The vessel was clearly well conditioned, amply supplied with provisions, and had a surgeon on board— There was evidently no intentional violation of the Law, and I directed a remission of the forfeiture— Tyler came to say he was going upon his mission to the Southern States to deliver the pamphlet Laws of the last Session; and he renewed his solicitation for some other appointment hereafter. Sadler was a man from Pennsylvania, who came with Boyd the watchman of the State Department, to see the President. Bresson is a Secretary of the French Legation, who came here with Baron Hyde de Neuville, on his last mission to this Country— He married one of judge Thomson’sdaughters and has a boy who cost the life of its mother— Bresson expected to have remained here as the Chargé d’Affaires of France after the departure of the Baron de Mareuil:—but the Count de Menou has already arrived to supersede him in that capacity, and he has therefore determined to return with Mareuil to France— He came and took leave— Commodores Hull and Crane with Lieutenant Gordon called for a morning visit— Hull lent me a paper containing a translation of an Address of O’Higgins, to the inhabitants of the Island of Chiloe, upon his attempt to rescue them from the Government of Chili— Governor Barbour took back the Letter from T. W Cobb the Georgian Senator, soliciting clemency for Cadet Campbell— I said he might write to Mr Cobb, that Campbell would not be dismissed; and asked him to give that direction at West-Point, in consideration of the youth and inexperience of the Cadet, and in the hope that he would have more regard for his own veracity hereafter— Mr Clay called and took the Letter from Mr Webster, which he sent me, and which he proposed to answer— He said he had also received one from J. W. Taylor— After dinner, Dr Thornton brought and introduced a Mr Restiff, a traveller from the Island of Santa Cruce— Mary Buchanan came to spend some days with Mrs Adams
15. IV:53. Precisely at Sun rise— Walk round City Hall, Tiber and Bridge Square

Mr Barnum came with a description of a machine which he has invented for surveying, and which he represents as greatly facilitating that operation. He has applied to take out a patent for it: but of the machine I could form no very distinct idea, and he promised to bring one of them to shew me hereafter. Mr Taliaferro is one of the members of the House of Representatives from Virginia, and has been recently re-elected. It was for the District represented by him that Henry Lee intended to offer as a Candidate, but he was not able to get up any shew of opposition to Taliaferro— He says Lee is now gone to visit General Jackson at Nashville— He is composing a Life of the General for publication— Mr Brent came to enquire if the Salary of Mr Ironside could be allowed for the benefit of his destitute widow and children for the remainder of the
quarter— I doubted. He said it had been allowed in a similar case, at the Treasury Department, by Mr Crawford— Mr Brent afterwards sent me at my request, the volumes of the British Statutes at Large, for the years 1783 and 1797. Also the Boston Patriot of last Friday, from which it appears that of thirty Representatives in the Legislature of the State, which were to have been elected, seven or eight only were chosen— George is not of the number— Mr Thorpe, Superintendent of two of the Public Buildings came to ask a loan of money to enable him to put a Steam-engine into a boat of his invention, to carry passengers between the Tiber Creek and Alexandria— I could not assist him— Governor Barbour brought me a Letter from T. M. Randolph, who was appointed as a Commissioner on the part of the United States to run the boundary line, between the State of Georgia, and the Territory of Florida— They have been stopped in the midst of their work, by an order from the Governor of Georgia— He left the Letter with me for consideration what is to be done— Governor Barbour asked some questions respecting the Slanders upon my Accounts, began in Congress and now circulating all over the Union in the newspapers— I told him the state of the facts, and he said he thought explanations should be given in the public prints— Mr Knapp came and introduced a Coll. Perkins from Connecticut as a visitor. Mr Rush had a Letter from Peleg Sprague of Maine, requesting him to consider as confidential two Letters from him, Sprague, written 3. March last, recommending J. K Gilman as Collector at Castine—confidential until Sprague himself could see them— Mr Rush spoke also of the unfortunate rashness of Condy Raguet, Chargé d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro, who has dismissed himself from that Office, by demanding and obtaining his Passports— A new example of a man’s casting to the winds the favours of Fortune— Mr Charles Tait was sometime a Senator from the State of Georgia— Then U.S. District judge, in Alabama, and is now a Citizen at large, travelling for his pleasure. He came on a visit of civility— Mary Roberdeau came again for a visit of a few days.
16. V:30— Cloudy— College-Hill walk.

Mr Southard came to enquire if there were any Instructions from the Department of State to be given to Captain Crane, who is now going to Norfolk, and thence to return to Boston— There he is to embark shortly in the Java Frigate, to go out and relieve Commodore Rodgers as Commander of the Squadron in the Mediterranean— He spoke also of complaints against a Midshipman named Green; and Penhallow an acting Midshipman, by special, and I fear undeserved favour from me— He thinks of appointing Tingey, as a Commissioner of the Navy, a service to which as I expected he finds Hull extremely averse— Mr Weightman the Mayor of the City came to speak of two subjects concerning which he some time since had brought me Resolutions of the Corporation— One relating to the graduation of the grounds; and the other about the compensation of the City Surveyor— On examining the Laws a doubt occurred to me by what authority the City Surveyor was appointed— Weightman said the present Surveyor was appointed last Summer by Mr Elgar; but the question is on the provision for his compensation— Mr. Brent came to say that the Count de Menou, had expressed a desire to pay me an informal visit; and he had informed him that unless I should otherwise direct he thought I would receive him at one O’Clock on Friday—to which I assented— Commodore’s Crane and Chauncey successively called upon me, to pay morning visits— The result of the election at Boston last Thursday, appears in the Boston Patriot of this day— Of the Union or Administration ticket, eight were elected— The twenty-two others having an average of six hundred votes more than any other person on any other ticket— The extremes of the federal, and of the Republican parties had each a ticket—the free bridge a ticket, and the Lottery-brokers a ticket. George’s name was discarded from all but the Union ticket; and had 1430 votes— The whole number given was 3169. and 1585 votes were necessary for a choice— A second trial for the 22 remaining members of the list is to take place to-morrow— I have been an hour or two of this day and the two preceding days occupied in signing 688 land-grants; and having written to R. Walsh junr. to inform him that I have not been able to finish the Article upon the British Colonial trade, have involuntarily relaxed something of my devotion to it— I snatched an hour of this Evening to read N. Biddle’s Eulogium upon Thomas Jefferson, with which I was much pleased—
17— V— Cloudy— Walk to Georgetown—

Upon this morning’s walk back from Georgetown, along the banks of the river I observed a large old tree which I had always taken for Oak, bearing Tulips in bloom—and after passing the House where Mr Hellen lived, and where I resided five successive Winters, while a member of the Senate, I found four large old trees on the brow of the Hill, were also Tulip-trees—two of them bearing flowers— Mr Larned called and introduced to me, a Dr James and another person, travellers from Albany N. York, returning home from a visit to Charleston, S.C. Governor Barbour brought the proceedings of the Court of Enquiry, upon allegations by Assistant Surgeon Weightman, against Lieutenant Alberti, of his having stolen from his desk a sum of near 300 dollars— These papers are almost as voluminous, as the West-Point trials— The Court of Enquiry, acquit Lieutt. Alberti most explicitly of the theft, and add that there is not the slightest evidence to charge him with it— But it is for making the charge, that Alberti earnestly demands that Weightman should be brought to trial, together with Paymaster Massias and Lieutenant Beckley, as conspirators with him to ruin by Slanderous accusations the character of Alberti— The Secretary of War has declined calling a Court-Martial, upon these Officers, and Alberti has appealed to me— Governor Barbour has examined the proceedings of the Court of Enquiry, and thinks that if Weightman is tried by a Court-Martial they will acquit him of all malice, which will make Alberti’s case worse than it now stands— He says it appears in Evidence in the proceedings of the Court of Enquiry, that Weightman’s suspicions were not without colour— He left the Papers with me— Mr Rush had a private Letter from J. Binns at Philadelphia, informing him that Judge Gibson would be appointed Chief Justice of Pennsylvania, and of some other circumstances of political concern— He had also a Letter from D. Green, Editor of the U. States Telegraph, requesting from a Kentuckey member of Congress, a copy of the accounts of all the members of Congress from that State for the monies received by them for pay and travel at the last Session— He said he should decline furnishing it, unless at the direct application of the member himself— Mr Clay mentioned that he had indirect information of the resignation of the Marshal, in Missouri, though no letter from the Marshal himself. He thought it would however be necessary to make an appointment— The weather is at last growing warm, and I was this evening obliged to abandon my writing table— Mary Buchanan this day left us—
18. IV:30. Sun rose 4:50. Garden walk—

Instead of my usual four miles walk before breakfast, I made this morning a tour of the garden, and had some conversation with the gardener, an Irishman by the name of Ouseley— I found in the garden a great number of plants, herbs, flowers, and weeds to the names of which I was a stranger. Some of them were unknown to him— There are of Fruit trees in the garden, one red mulberry, Several Peaches; more plumbs; a few cherries and three or four Hazel nut shrubs— Of flowering trees one Tulip, now in bloom, a large Weeping willow; one Ash, and one Florida Cornus dogwood— An Althea, and a White-thorn hedge— Many flowering Plants—and culinary vegetables—Potatoes, Carrots, Beets, Radishes, Cabbages, Cauliflower, Lettuces, Peas, Beans, Jerusalem Artichokes, Onions, Garlick, Shives, and Asparagus— There are other Roots and fruits which escaped my notice; and two sorts of Strawberries, the creeping Scarlet and the towering hautboy— I noticed two or three shoots of peach trees, this years growth, from buds which he told me he had inoculated last July upon Plumb-stock Suckers— The Plumb trees he said had never born, though they now present a fair shew of fruit— The old Peach trees looked sickly, and on examining near the ground one of them we found under the bark two of the destructive white worms—the Algeria exitiosa— After returning to the House, I took out the first Volume of Du Hamel du Monceau’s Physique des Arbres, and read a few pages of its Preface, and thought if I had made these Observations, and applied to this reading forty years since, and perseveringly pursued them to this time, I should have had some smattering of gardening
Botany, dendrology, and natural History— Non omnia possumus omnes— Mr Southard came and reported verbally to me, on the proceedings of the Court of Enquiry upon the charges of Captain Kuhn against Coll. Henderson and Lieutenant Hall— He thought there was no sufficient ground for further proceedings against Henderson, and that he would order him to duty— With regard to Hall, he said it would be necessary that he should make a report in writing— Mr Clay spoke of an agreement which he had drawn up for employing Mr Jared Sparks to prepare for publication the Correspondence of the Old Congress during the Revolutionary War, according to a Resolution of Congress of 27. March 1818—which has not yet been carried into execution— I approved of the terms proposed, and to which Mr Sparks is prepared to assent. Mr Clay mentioned a Letter that he had received from B. Hardin, formerly a member of Congress from Kentuckey, and now a Candidate for the Senate of the State— Coll. Jones the adjutant General came and explained to me the necessity of issuing a new rule in place of the army regulation N. 1124— The rule is that a brevet Officer shall receive the pay of his brevet rank, only when he has a command equal to that rank— The rule proceeds to define a Captains Command to be a Company—A Major’s and Lieutenant Colonel’s, a Battalion—a Colonel’s a Regiment a Brigadier General’s a Brigade, and a Major General’s a division. Now the accounting Officers consider a Battalion, to mean half a Regiment, or five Companies— But Captains, who are Majors by Brevet, having command of two Companies, think themselves entitled to the pay and emoluments of Majors, as much as if their command was of five Companies; and Jones says there is no definition of the term Battalion, requiring that it should be of five Companies, or even of half a regiment; some regiments consisting of three Battalions and some of nine Companies— I took the matter for further Consideration— Major Thornton, Major Hunter, and another Militia Officer from Alexandria, came as a Committee from the Officers of that Brigade of the District Militia, to protest against the appointment of General Walter Smith as Major General— Smith was Brigadier General of Washington County Brigade; and Walter Jones of that of Alexandria— They left with me a written remonstrance against Smith, whom they charge with having abdicated his brigadier’s command for at least ten years after the peace and they claim the appointment of Jones as Major General, for more faithful service, and even prior Commission— They stated that Jones had resigned his Commission as a Brigadier, since Smith’s appointment as Major-General— We had company to dine. Mr and Mrs Clay— General and Mrs. Macomb, General and Mrs John Mason, Mr and Mrs John Mason junr.Mr. and Mrs Gales, Mrs Johnston of Louisiana, Commodores Hull and Chauncey, and Lieutenant Gordon— Captain Crane, and Mr Taliaferro were invited, but sent excuses—
19: IV.45. Sun rose 4:49.— Potowmack Bath

I Swam in the river this morning about ten minutes, and then spent an hour in the Garden, weeding with the hand my seedling bed— Read the remainder of Du Hamel du Monceau’s Preface to his Physique des Arbres— There are two Quarto Volumes of this work, but he closes the Preface, by observing that he pretends not to have exhausted the subject in them; but will pursue it in subsequent volumes and exhorts those who would thoroughly understand this part of Physical Science to consult the works of Malphigi, Grew, Hales, Bonnet, many Dissertations scattered through the Memoirs of the Academy of Sciences, the Philosophical Transactions, the German Ephemerides, and particular Memoirs of Linnaeus, and others— Here is the labour of years. Mr Graham brought me a Letter from James Kilbourn of the State of Ohio, complaining of the determination to remove the land Office from Delaware to Tiffin—he now proposes that it should be fixed at Bucyrus— I advised Mr Graham to write to Mr Bartley the member from Ohio, at whose instance, the location was made at Tiffin—to inform him of the substance of Mr Kilbourn’s observations, and to wait for his answer before coming to a final decision: He had also a Letter from John Kilbourn, concerning
a grant of Land, made by an Act of Congress at their last Session. (3. March 1827. Ch. 93) to the State of Ohio, for the purpose of making a road from Columbus to Sandusky— Kilbourn is one of the Trustees appointed by the Legislature of the State to make the road, and makes a question whether the grant was to the State or to the Trustees— I told Mr Graham the grant was to the State, the Trustees not being ever mentioned in the Law— There was another question upon the construction of the Act, the present decision upon which became unnecessary— Mr Fürst the Medalist came to renew the solicitation of Patronage, and employment— He complained that he could not find a market for the medals he had struck on the occasion of my inauguration— Of this there are two causes— The medals are not remarkably well executed, and there is little taste for collecting and preserving medals in this Country— I told him there was no vacant employment that I could give him, and he said, he must then break up his establishment— Governor Barbour came and took Mr T— M— Randolph’s Letter, announcing the discontinuance by order of the Governor of Georgia, of the Surveys for running the line between that State and Florida. Mr Randolph is to be recalled, and directed to ascertain the cause of the suspension of the work, by the Governor of Georgia. Governor Barbour mentioned also an Application by Mr Force, publisher of the National Journal, for a copy of the order given by General Jackson in January 1815. for the execution of six Militia-men as mutineers. This is one of the charges urged against him in the electioneering campaign— Some time since a Meeting of General Jackson’s friends at Nashville, appointed a standing Committee to defend his character and reputation against Slander— They have published a vindication of his conduct on this occasion, signed John Overton, chairman of the Jackson Committee— They have given a copy of the order for the trial of the Militiamen, some extracts from the proceedings of the Court-Martial, certified by Andrew J Donelson, and an Affidavit Certificate of Philip Pipkin, Colonel of the Regiment to which the mutineers belonged— They were shot for mutiny by sentence of a Court Martial; and the Committee and Colonel Pipkin, urge that General Jackson had nothing to do in the affair but to order the Court Martial— The order from General Jackson, confirming the sentence of the Court, is at the War Department, and Force applies for a copy of it for publication in the Journal— I observed to Governor Barbour, that to furnish this document at the application of a Printer, would be perhaps a departure from the general rule of the Departments and would be considered as a measure of hostility to General Jackson— I thought it should therefore be declined— Mr Lee read me an extract of a Letter from G. Blake at Philadelphia, mentioning that Mr Mills was decidedly convalescent— Mr Southard came with Commodore Chauncey, and a plan of the Navy-Yard at Brooklyn, opposite to New-York, shewing the portion of the land, the title of which is now contested, by the Town of Brooklyn, and by several individuals, it is covered with water, and when purchased by the United States was a Mill pond— The claimants own land bordering on the pond, and affirm that the right of overflowing it was conditional, to the grinding of corn for the People of Brooklyn, at the Mill— The United States have had possession of upwards of twenty years which it is said gives in New-York a prescriptive title— And there is also an absolute Deed, from Commissioners of New-York— Mr Southard mentioned also another question of title, to another part of the land— The Deed being to the Commissioners of Navy Hospitals, and not to the United States. I wrote this Evening with difficulty; and must soon suspend evening writing for the Summer.
20. V:5 Cloudy.

Heard this morning Mr Little from 1. Corinthians 6:11 “And such were some of you: but ye are washed but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in the name of the Lord Jesus, and by the Spirit of our God.” He assumed this text as one of those upon which the Calvinistic doctrine of regeneration, and election are supported— He gave what he considered to be the true meaning of the text— It was reformation of life in the Corinthians and other Christians to whom the Epistle was addressed, from gross moral vices, by their conversion to Christianity, which was all that he understood by the name of the Lord Jesus, and the Spirit of our God— I believe however there is an allusion to the rite of baptism which they had received, and
which he did not notice. He then canvassed the Calvinistic dogma of regeneration, with much severity, and sarcastic humour, glancing also at the Armenian creed, which he considered as not less absurd— He reprobated altogether the idea of the total depravity of the human heart, as equally unjust and dishonourable to human nature, tending to reduce the good and evil to one common level, and to rob virtue of her due reward the acknowledgment of her existence— It is indeed an easy task for a controversialist of one Christian Sect to expose the absurdities of another— In the afternoon I heard at Mr Baker’s, the Methodist Minister, now stationed at the Foundery Church, Davis: and his text was the last clause of 2. Corinthians 6.2. “Behold now is the day of Salvation”— He began by asserting that very total depravity of man, which the morning Sermon had so earnestly denied—and quoted a good saying of some Saint that this world was God’s rebellious Province; which I do not suppose it is more than any other of the Planets— He alluded to the Sermon preached in the same pulpit last Sunday afternoon, and intimated a connection of purpose with it— Both were intentionally pathetic appeals to unconverted sinners to turn from the error of their ways, now—on the very day of Salvation— In the evening at St. John’s Church I heard Mr Henry Van Dyke Johns, from Psalm 39.5. [“]Behold thou hast made my days as an hairbreadth; and mine age is as nothing before thee: verily every man at his best state is altogether vanity”— An eloquent discourse from a young man, upon the brevity of human life— The Ladies were there and Mr Southard walked home with us.
21. IV:45. Garden— Short Square walk— Showery—

I shortened my Morning’s walk to about half an hour, and employed the remaining hour devoted to exercise in weeding with the hand the seedling bed in the garden— Then read part of the Dissertation upon Methods of Botany, which follows the Preface of Du Hamel du Monceau’s Physique des Arbres— He gives a summary Statement of the various methods of Morrison, Ray, Tournefort, Magnol, and Linnaeus, which in 1758 when this work was published was new; but has since superseded all the others— Dr Todsen came with two additional Letters of recommendation, with Statements that the Court Martial which tried him was prejudiced and hostile to him, and with a renewed solicitation for an appointment— I told him I could say nothing further to him than I had already said. Mr Clay brought a Letter, recommending a Mr Mason, for the appointment of Postmaster at Newport— The Letter was from A. Robbins, the Senator— I had received one from D. J. Pearce, the member of the House, recommending a Mr Cranston— The appointment is to be made by the Postmaster General— Mr Clay said he should send this morning his Letter to Mr Obregon the Mexican Minister, complaining of Commodore Porters using the neutral position at Key-west, as a station of annoyance against Spain— Mr Clay spoke of his intention to visit Kentucky in June, to return here before the first of August; and of his wish afterwards to visit the Bedford Springs, towards the close of Summer. Commodore Warrington, introduced to me Mr Hodges of Norfolk, Virginia as a visitor— A Mr Allanson came to make application for some appointment, without specifying what— He has been educated at West-Point, and was a Captain in the army, and Aid de camp to General Miller, until his appointment as Governor of the Territory of Arkansas— He then resigned his Commission, and has been engaged in commercial business at New-York, without success— He thinks himself competent for employment as an engineer— He brought me a Letter of recommendation from De Grand, mentioning him as a nephew of the late Mr William Gray of Boston— I advised him to confine his application to some particular Office; and to have it filed at the proper Department— Mr Rush brought a Letter from W. Jones the Collector at Philadelphia, recommending a person named Kneass, for second Lieutenant of the Revenue Cutter, to which I assented— We spoke of the recent change of ministry in Great-Britain, the triumphant ascendency of Canning, and the unfavourable consequences which may be expected to follow from it, to our Negotiations with that Government— Mr Rush in this Conversation expressed a more favourable opinion of the Duke of Wellington than he had heretofore entertained—
22. V:30.— Round Capitol Square— Showery.

The wetness of the ground superseded my morning visit to the Garden, and I only walked round the Capitol Square— Then finished reading Du Hamel’s Dissertation upon methods of Botany—and began the work itself; which treats first of the trunk—then of the Bark— Of the first portion of which, the epidermis, comparing it with that of animals he says— Nothing satisfactory has yet been seen or said, of the formation, the regeneration, or even the tissue of the animal or vegetable epidermis— I cast a desultory look into the Volume upon seeding and planting— Mr Pleasonton came with the papers of recommendation for the appointment of two Light-house keepers— I have had several days on my table those of a third. Each of them is of itself a volume— These petty offices, are sought after with an avidity of competition, as eager as those upon which the destiny of the Nation depends— It is a little fortune for a man with a wife and children; and the melancholy side of the subject is, that when the man dies, there is a destitute family to be turned upon the world, unless the widow or the Son can be appointed to the vacated place— Here is an affecting application from the widow— She has kept the light, for ten months before her husband died— She has testimony that it is the best light, in all Long-Island Sound, or even between New-York and Boston: she has two Sons, one of them 27 years old— But Pleasonton shakes his head, and says his experience is discouraging to the appointment of widows—for the first that was appointed, was soon found out by an Irish fortune-hunter, who married her for her light-house, and then the light became darkness— Governor Barbour brought me a Letter from John Myers of Norfolk, concerning the custom house debt due from his father, in answer to one which the Governor had written him— I gave Govr Barbour papers relating to the Stocks in the name of the President of the United States, in trust for the Seneca Indians, requesting him to obtain some further information, respecting the management of this fund hitherto; and with a view to put it into some form of systematic management to guard against neglect and abuses hereafter. Mr Rush had a Letter from J. J. Crittenden, U.S. District Attorney in Kentucky, noting ten or twelve causes to which the United States are parties, pending in the U.S. District and Circuit Courts of that District; which he cannot prosecute; having been Counsel for the Defendants before his appointment as District Attorney— He asks that other Counsel may be appointed for those causes, and recommends the Attorney General of the State, which I approved— A Mr Hager from Kentuckey and a Mr Irons from Washington County, Pennsylvania came upon a visit of curiosity— Mr Clay had sent me a Letter which he has received from the Baron de Mareuil, mentioning the equalization of impost and tonnage duties, between the United States and France, which was stipulated by the Convention of 24 June 1822, as having resulted altogether in favour of the former and that as after next October, if the Convention continues this equalization will be entire. France has a right to claim some compensating advantages to her commerce; such as a reduction of duties upon her brandies and vines, and an increased difference in favour of her Silks. Mr Clay thought this was altogether a movement of the Baron’s own head; but I supposed the result of Instructions brought to him by Count Menou— I advised an answer in general terms, that we shall very readily renew conferences with the French government upon the commercial and navigating interests of both Countries—as was stipulated by the Convention of 1822 itself.— The second trial for electing Representatives at Boston, again failed last Thursday.
23. V. Sun risen— Garden weeding

Garden weeding substituted for my usual morning walk; and I had a conversation with the gardener Ouseley upon Sea kale, in flower, Poppies, Bindweed, or Bistoota, Poligonium, Artemis, Mustard, and Periwinkle, herbs or weeds growing in the garden— Read in Du Hamel, of the cellular cloak, the cortical layers; the cellular tissue, and the proper vessels of bark, upon all which the information I collected was very indistinct— Mr Brent came for the contract between Mr Clay and Mr Sparks, for the publication of the old Correspondence in the Department of State, which I had approved— Governor Barbour informed me that Duff Green, Editor of the Telegraph, had applied for a copy of General Jackson’s order, upon the proceedings of the Court-Martial, on the trial of the six Militia-men, who were executed for mutiny; and said he had seen in a Kentucky paper that General Jackson had nothing to do with it; but that the execution had been ordered by General Winchester— This order of General Jackson, Governor thought it might be proper to give now, both to Green, and to Force who had applied for it before— I still thought there would be inconvenience in furnishing documents from Public Officers, at the mere application of Editors of Newspapers; but I left the decision to his discretion— Billing came with an order from W. W. Seaton, and R. C. Weightman, for my contribution to the erection of the Masonic Hall— P. Force called to say that Mr M’lean the Postmaster General was desirous of publishing in the National Journal, an Article in answer to a published Letter addressed to him by J. Binns, in the Democratic Press— I told him I could have no objection to this— There is an opinion abroad that the Postmaster General is hostile to the Administration: which he however very earnestly disclaims. His conduct is ambiguous; and he is much devoted to Mr Calhoun; bearing also no friendship to Mr Clay. This position and these feelings have prompted him to acts, adverse in their effects to the Administration, and give countenance to the prevailing opinion of his hostility to it— As he is an able and efficient Officer, I have made every allowance for the peculiarity of his situation, and have not believed him wilfully treacherous— Mr Myers came concerning the appointment of his father as Collector at Norfolk; upon which I have at length concluded. Mr Farrow came to introduce a Mr Adams from Virginia, whose visit was one of curiosity—and Farrow likewise introduced himself—
24. V. Potowmac bath— Swam 10 minutes— Garden weeding.

Coll. Waters is an old Revolutionary Officer residing in Maryland, who was one of the Candidates for the appointment of Marshal of that District at the last vacancy. His son is now applying for an appointment as a Purser in the Navy, and he came to make interest in his behalf. I believe there is no appointment at present to be made. Mr Slade came to make some enquiries, respecting the transmission heretofore, of the annual pamphlet copies of the Laws of the United States from the Department of State, to the Governors of the several States— He wants the facts to rejoin upon the reply of C. P. Van Ness—the disappointed Candidate for the Senate of the United States from Vermont, who after fawning professions of preference for me, and of attachment to the Administration, to obtain the election, and failing in it, published an Address to the People, declaring himself converted to the cause of General Jackson for the next Presidential election, and charging me, with having interfered with the Legislature of Vermont against his election as Senator— This was utterly without foundation; and his evidence is so remote from proof that he mixes about four parts of his own suspicions, with one part of fact to sustain his charge— Being himself a deep intriguer, and knowing the power of trifles light as air to the jealous, he made an argument of several columns to prove my interference against him, because just before the election, Mr Buck, a member of the House of Representatives of Vermont, received a Letter from Mr
John Bailey, expressing his wish that Mr Seymour might be re-elected; and in a Postscript to the same Letter, mentioned that I was to leave Boston that day for Washington— This Letter was shewn by Buck to several members of the Legislature, and Van Ness says changed the votes of a number sufficient to defeat his election, which it very probably did— And so he to revenge himself charges it upon me, as a personal interference against him— Bailey published an answer, denying that he had ever had any conversation with me concerning that Senatorial election in Vermont, when he wrote his Letter to Buck; and otherwise chastising Van Ness, to which he has replied by a publication of eight Newspaper Columns which I have not seen— Another of Van Ness’s imputations is because Mr Slade was last Summer employed to carry to Vermont, and other Eastern States the Laws of the preceding Session of Congress— Slade was in the State shortly before the Election, and perhaps freely expressed his opinions about Van Ness and in favour of Seymour— Slade is a Clerk in the Department of State; and was sent by Mr Clay— Therefore I, who was at Quincy and knew nothing of this arrangement, interfered in this Election— So reasons C. P. Van Ness. Slade also answered Van Ness, utterly denying his imputations and almost all his statements of fact— To him also Van Ness has replied; and Slade intends to rejoin— Van Ness makes me his object of attack, to give himself importance, and finding all his chances desperate under my standard, recommends himself to the adversary by a venomous shaft at the leader whom he deserts— Mr Clay mentioned an interview which he had yesterday with the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires Rebello, upon Mr Raguet’s demand of his Passports at Rio de Janeyro; and the Affair of the Spark. Rebello declares that his Government are earnestly desirous of being upon the best terms with that of the United States, and will be happy to receive another Minister in the place of Mr Raguet— They offer explanations upon the affair of the Spark, and seem to admit that they have some reparation to make— Mr Clay has requested him to reduce his observations into the form of a note, which he has promised, and Mr Clay proposed a meeting of the Members of the Administration, upon this, and also upon an Instruction that he has prepared for Mr Brown at Paris relating to our Claims upon the French Government— I agreed to this meeting, for Saturday at one O’Clock— Mr Clay mentioned that he had heard of the arrival of his Son, at Vera-Cruz— He was the bearer of the conditionally ratified Treaty— Mr Clay thinks Mr Poinsett has indiscreetly connected himself with party movements, and political masonry in Mexico— Mr M’lean the Postmaster General introduced to me a Mr Davis from Cincinnati in Ohio. He also spoke of Binns’s published Letter to him— He proposes to answer it, by an Article in the National Journal— Binns repeats the old complaint of his Letter to Mr Markley, which was delayed by an accident at the Post-Office here, and some improper conduct, of a nature altogether private, in of Richard Bache the Philadelphia Postmaster last Summer at Cape May. To this he now adds a complaint against the Postmaster at Carlisle, founded however much upon suspicion: of his having furnished a list of the names of persons who received the Democratic Press from that Post-Office, to a person who prevailed upon six of them to withdraw their subscriptions at once— Mr M’lean said he would make enquiry into that affair, and if the fact should turn out as surmised by Binns, would dismiss the Postmaster— Mr Rush called to enquire if a Commission should be made out for Moses Myers as Collector at Norfolk to which I assented— He mentioned the answer he had received from Dr Mease enclosing a list of useful trees and plants which might be introduced into this Country— He said he had addressed similar enquiries to Dr Hosack of New-York, and Dr Bigelow of Boston— I advised him to address like Letters to Stephen Elliot of Charleston S.C. and to judge Brackenridge at Pensacola. Mr Seaton came and introduced a Frenchman, Mr Isidore Guillet, who brought me a Letter recommendatory from R. Walsh junr. and who gave me some reason for not bringing one from his particular friend General La Fayette— Captain Hull called to take leave; going to morrow for New-York on a furlough. He shewed
me two Letters to him from Paul Hamilton, Secretary of the Navy dated 26. and 27. July 1812—the first of which ordered him to deliver up the frigate Constitution to Captain Bainbridge— This Letter he accidentally did not receive, before he sailed on the Cruize upon which he took the Guerriere— Mr Sparks came to take leave going to morrow for Boston— I had a Conversation with him, on the plan upon which he is to prepare for publication the Correspondence of the old Congress— Dr Watkins brought me a Letter from H. Niles, with one enclosed to him, concerning the appointment of a Light-house keeper at Cape Henlopen— Watkins told me also that he had been informed a hostile use against me, would soon be made of a Letter written by me to a person in the State of New-York; which he described so that I knew, it must be the Letter which I lately wrote to Elkanah Watson— I got my Letter Book and read him the Letter; and asked him what could be made of that— He said, nothing—when the occasion of its being written was explained. Evening occupied in writing.
25. V. Swam from the Boat 10 minutes— Weeding.

The bath and the garden weeding occupied three hours of exercise, inducing bodily fatigue— I persevere in seeking health by laborious exercise, but with not entire success. Joseph Marshall a Quaker belonging to Greenville, Tennessee came to indulge his curiosity in a visit.
