He is a young man little turned of 21. and told me that he had been for some years occupied chiefly upon the plan of that Christian Society for promoting the emancipation of Slaves— He said that he had travelled in North and South Carolina, in this vocation, and that in a great portion of those States, such was the terror in which the white people lived, from their own Slaves, that no planter ever slept at Night, without keeping a candle burning all night, in his bed chamber, and his rifle loaded, at his bed-side— He spoke of politics, as these Stranger visitants scarcely ever fail to do— While he was here Eckloff the Tailor came upon his professional visit. Mr. Heman Lincoln was afterwards here, and spoke of the Affairs of the Columbian College, which has recently broken up, owing to the mismanagement of their affairs, and an enormous load of debt, which they have contracted and cannot discharge— He said the Baptist denomination, were aware that their honour and credit were affected by this State of things, and he hoped that something would be done to retrieve them— But that the management of their affairs must first be taken out of the hands of O. B Brown and L. Rice— I shewed him the obligations of the College to me; and said although I had never given them any trouble about them, I expected they would ultimately take measures for doing Justice— Mr Brent came to enquire for one or two volumes of the correspondence, to be prepared for publication by Mr Sparks— He afterwards sent me at my request the first Volume of the Reports of Mr Jefferson while Secretary of State, as well to the two Houses of Congress as to President Washington— Also the first Volume of A. Hamiltons Works, published at New-York in 1810. containing his principal Reports— Among them is an argument, submitted to the President, on the Constitutionality of a National Bank, in answer to arguments against it which had been written by the Secretary of State, T. Jefferson, and the Attorney General, Edmund Randolph— But Mr Jefferson’s argument, is not in the Volumes of his Reports, recorded at the Department of State. Nor is the Report, of which I found last Summer among my fathers papers—wherein he maintains that upon a nomination to a mission abroad, the Senate had no constitutional right to decide upon the expediency of the Mission. I rode this afternoon with my Son John in his Gig, to the Penitentiary, the Navy-yard, and the lower Eastern branch Bridge—returned just at the close of the dusk of Evening— I was able to read this day only a very few pages of Du Hamel upon the wood of trees and omitted writing upon the Colonial trade question altogether. I sowed in my seed bed towards the East end of the garden 15 cherry stones, continued weeding with the hand, the bed in which I sowed last November—Walnuts, Chesnuts, Pecan nuts, and Acorns, none of which have yet appeared.
26. V. Fog— Potowmac bath. Weeding— 21 Cherry Stones sowed—

Mr William Lee introduced two young Frenchmen from Bordeaux, traveling for information, and last from Mexico— They are now upon their return to France, and expect to embark at New-York for Havre on the first of July— Cabinet Meeting from one till four. Two subjects under consideration. First the state of affairs with Brazil— Mr Clay has not yet received the expected written communication from Mr Rebello. There are three questions relative to the re-establishment of our mission to Rio de Janeyro. First whether any person shall be sent— Second—whether a Chargé d’Affaires, or a Minister Plenipotentiary— and third, at what time— There was much desultory discussion, and a final conclusion to defer the further consideration of the subject till Mr Rebello’s note shall have been received. If with a view to the negotiation of a Treaty of Commerce a Minister Plenipotentiary should be sent that measure must be postponed until the Meeting of Congress—and it is to be weighed whether a renewal of the mission should be made, without a previous assurance from the Brazilian Government that reparation shall be made for the seizure of the Spark—and whether that case shall be discriminated from other causes of complaint, or a pledge required for satisfaction upon them all— There was some allusion to the proceedings of this Government and the British in the affair of the Chesapeake and of the Leopard; and also to the transactions with the Russian Government in the case of the Pearl— The adjustment of differences of this description between Nations is a matter of great delicacy, and in the progress of which a single false step leads to disastrous and humiliating consequences— The Second subject of deliberation to the Cabinet, was a Letter of Instructions, to Mr. Brown, our Minister at Paris, concerning the claims of indemnity of many Citizens of the United States upon the French Government; for wrongs and spoliations committed during the revolutionary Wars. The complaints are of long standing, and for injuries to a very large amount— The french Government have refused to discuss them, unless in connection with a claim which they have raised of special favours to French Navigation in Louisiana, under the Treaty of Cession— This claim rests upon a Construction of the eighth Article of the Treaty which we have rejected as inadmissible— Mr Clay’s Letter of Instruction now directed Mr Brown to renew the demand of indemnity for the claims of our Citizens; and to offer to refer the question upon the Construction of the Louisiana Treaty to the arbitration of a friendly Sovereign, or of a Commission of foreigners to be agreed upon between the two Governments—and if the French Government should agree to refer the Louisiana question upon condition that the claims should also be referred to the same arbitration, Mr Brown was instructed to agree to it. Mr Rush objected to this reference of the claims as did Governor Barbour, I thought with good reason. I suggested that the claimants themselves might make it a ground of future claim against this Government— Mr Clay thought the prospects of the Claimants would be improved by submission to an arbitration, but agreed to modify his Letter of instruction to Mr Brown, so that the proposal of arbitration should be confined to the question upon the Louisiana Convention. I have little confidence in anything that we can now do for the attainment of indemnity for these claims, and believe that the only benefit to be expected from this instruction will be to shew that they are not abandoned by the Government, and to serve as the foundation of a Report concerning them to Congress at the next Session— I read a few pages of Du Hamel’s Physique des Arbres and shortened my evening’s writing upon the Colonial trade, to hear Miss Roberdeau’s voice and Piano.
27. V. Thick fog.

Heard Mr Little from Luke 11.3. “Give us day by day, our daily bread”— This discourse was not sectarian, but practical— He stated that the necessity of prayer could not be denied by a Christian. And there can be no doubt that Prayer is a Christian duty. In the second Alcibiades of Plato, Socrates teaches his young friend to be very cautious in selecting the objects of prayer, lest in praying for a good, he should obtain an evil— He approves therefore of prayer in general terms, referring to the Power to whom the prayer is addressed the particular objects to be granted— In the Lords prayer, the petitions are four—daily bread—by which must be understood provision for all the wants of the body—Forgiveness of Sins—not to be led into temptation—and deliverance from evil— It is to be observed that the latter of these two Petitions are in substance the same as the prayer approved by Socrates— Mr Little assigned four distinct motives for the petition for daily bread, and shewed with cogency the reasons why this prayer is as obligatory upon the rich as upon the poor, and why the poor in addressing it to the Supreme Creator, should associate with it, the use of their own exertions to make it effective— In the afternoon I heard Mr Campbell at Mr Baker’s, from Matthew 5.3. “Blessed are the poor in Spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of Heaven.” A well delivered discourse upon humility— He related the anecdote of Demosthenes; giving action as the first, second and third qualification of an Orator, and he approved the application by one of the fathers, of this Story, to humility, as the first second and third of Christian virtues— Humility is no doubt, an excellent and a truly Christian virtue,—but it is a negative and a passive virtue— The virtue including all other Christian graces according to St. Paul is Charity—or active benevolence— In the Evening I heard again Mr Little from John 14.30. [“]Hereafter I will not talk much with you: for the prince of this world cometh, and hath nothing in me. 31. But that the world may know that I love the Father; and as the father gave me commandment so I do. Arise, let us go hence.” The solemn and careful occasion upon which these words were spoken, is duly noticed. The profound impression which they must have made upon the disciples, and the heavy tidings which they carried to them were remarked— There was a long critical discussion who was meant by the Prince of this world, and an anxious argument to shew that it was not the devil— This he satisfactorily proved, and gave strong reasons for concluding that it meant the Roman and Jewish Authorities, Civil, military and Ecclesiastical— But he cannot touch this topic without falling into sectarianism, and he enlarged his digression, by the affirmance that there was no warrant in scripture, for believing in the existence of any such being as the devil— The day was warm— I took a ride in the Carriage after dinner with Mrs Adams, Mary and Johnson Hellen; but I could not write after returning home this Evening from Church— No Letter this whole week from George— I wrote one of three lines to him. I read some pages in Du Hamel du Monceau—but have no time to pursue the perusal of his works, regularly, and now left his work upon the Physics of Trees, to consult the volume upon seeding and planting, and plunged into the midst of that— It appears that Du Hamel, is the most systematic writer upon forests and woods of modern times— I meet however with a difficulty at the threshold, in understanding a great multitude of the words used: a difficulty complicated at once by the language and the subject— I collected likewise some observations by looking into Prince’s Catalogue of his trees, plants and flowers at his nursery at Flushing on Long-Island— This is the oldest Institution of the kind in the United States, having been commenced by the father of the present proprietor, before the American Revolution— One of the stumbling blocks to my project is the danger of enlarging it till it shall become impracticable— Another is of wasting time upon mere fancies without executing any thing— I find in Du Hamel many useful remarks upon the time of sowing the seeds of Stones and Trees in fall or Spring, and also upon the means of keeping them over Winter— My health is yet unpromising. Potted 9. Orange seeds.
28. V:45. Swam from the Boat. 10. minutes— Showery— Garden weeding.

Doctor Watkins came with a Letter to him from J. Binns of Philadelphia, mentioning the Letter addressed to the Postmaster General, and published last week in the Democratic Press— He says that in consequence of that publication R. Bache the Postmaster at Philadelphia, has committed a violent Assault and Battery upon his person— That he should take no notice of it in his paper; but had written a Letter to the Postmaster General, of which he enclosed to Watkins a copy which he might shew to me— But this enclosed Letter was sealed, and being addressed to Mr M’lean, Watkins scrupled his right to open it, and I thought he would do well to wait for express authority to that purpose— Mr Graham brought me five Proclamations for Sales of Lands, at various Offices, which I signed. General Parker came again for a decision by way of appeal from the accounting Officers upon his claims for double Rations and other allowances while he was Adjutant and Inspector General— He claims upon the ground of the allowances having been made to other Officers having no better pretensions than him— But Mr Calhoun while Secretary of War, decided in their favour, and decided against him— I told General Parker that I doubted the legality of Mr Calhoun’s favourable decision, and must decline considering it as a precedent which would justify me in issuing a special order, to extend the allowance to him, against Mr Calhoun’s decision; and observed that I had declined sanctioning the allowances granted by Mr Calhoun, by assenting to the arrearages of the same allowances claimed by the Officers to whom they were made— Mr Lincoln introduced two Baptist Clergymen—Missionaries—British Subjects—Mr Yates from Calcutta, and Mr Bourn from the Bay of Honduras; the former of whom gave me a small volume, containing the Specimen of printing types in use at the baptist mission press at Calcutta— The Specimens are of English, Greek, Hebrew Persian, Arabic, Hindustanee, Sanscrit, Hinduee, Bengalee, Ooriya, Pali, Burman and Goozurattee Languages— He told me there had been upwards of three thousand widows burnt alive in Hindustan last year— I asked Mr Bourne some questions about the trees that bear the logwood and mahogany at the Bay of Honduras; but he knew little of it— Mr Rush read to me the Letter which he wrote to W. Jones Collector at Philadelphia, on Saturday proposing to him to act as his proxy, at the meeting of the Stockholders of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal— I sent for Mr D. Brent and requested him to have a reprieve for John B. Amedey made out till further order— Chief Justice Marshall pronounced sentence of Death upon him last week— The order of respite was sent to me and I signed it— Mr Southard brought again the papers of the Court of Enquiry upon Coll. Henderson and Lieutenant Hall— After full consideration it was concluded to be most expedient that Hall should be tried by a Court Martial— Mr Hagner came to introduce his Son in Law, Nicholson, son of the late Joseph Nicholson who was a member of Congress from Maryland— Mr Barbour brought me a Letter from T. M. Randolph, announcing the close of the Commission for drawing the line between Georgia and Florida— He represents the Creek Indians of the Mackintosh party as in a starving condition— Governor Barbour took General Gaines’s Letter of self vindication, to reply to it— His answer though not satisfactory is such as may be received— J. H. Clark Consul of the United States from Lubeck, called to pay a visit— He is last from the Havana, and is proceeding to New-York there to embark on his return to Europe. He spoke of our great and increasing trade with the Island of Cuba— Recently increased in consequence of the War between Buenos Ayres and Brazill; by a demand for Salt beef and fish instead of the jerk’d beef of South-America—
29. IV:30. Cloudy— Swam from the Boat 10 minutes— Nuts uncovered.

As none of the Nuts or Acorns which I planted last November and December have yet appeared above ground, I this morning caused Antoine to turn over with a Spade the ground where they were deposited— Of the Quincy Shellbarks, not a trace was to be found in the rows where they were planted— Of the Spanish Chesnuts from judge Peters’s, five or six were found—rotten—with worm holes in the shells, and the nut apparently devoured by worms. One of the Princetown Chesnuts was found, also rotten and one Pennsylvania nut, vegetating with a shoot two inches long, and so near the surface, that it would probably have appeared in the course of the next Month. I then determined to leave the remaining rows undisturbed some time longer, with a hope that a very few of the nuts may yet come up; and a conviction that if my planting projects are ever to succeed for any useful purpose it must be by increased theoretic enquiry and practical observation— Mr Joseph Bailey was a young man from Fauquier County Virginia, who told me that he had come here about a fortnight since, with a very fine horse for Sale, but had not succeeded, and intending to depart to morrow Morning upon his return home, he called to see me for curiosity’s sake— Before the close of his visit he said he had got out of money and asked me to lend him thirty dollars— I ordered of Mr Price a small box, of the size of a match case for memorial, and for use— Mr Brent brought a Petition from Richard Prichard, Master of the British Brig Gomer arrived at New-York with a number of Passengers exceeding the allowance, by our Statute, though within the rule of the Act of Parliament— The vessel has been seized for the forfeiture, and the Captain sued for the penalty— I ordered a remission of both upon payment of the costs. Mr Rush was here with many papers— Among them numerous Certificates and depositions, forwarded by the Collector of Elizabeth City, against Daniel Long, the dismissed Inspector at Elizabeth City— Mr Dorsey the member of the House of Representatives from Maryland came in, and abridged Mr Rush’s conversation with me— General Politics, and electioneering topics, appear to be almost the only materials of interesting discourses, to men in the public service— There are in several of the States, at this time, and Maryland is one of them, Meetings, and Countermeetings, Committees of Correspondence, Delegations and Addresses, against and for the Administration, and thousands of persons occupied with little else than to work up the passions of the people preparatory to the Presidential Election still more than eighteen Months distant— Coll. Roberdeau called, and spoke of his Essay upon the Militia— He also invited me from Coll. Armistead, to go with the Ladies to morrow on a visit to Fort Warburton, seven miles below Alexandria— But I declined— Mr Clay mentioned that Mr Rebello the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires had again been with him; and expressed his willingness to write a Note, giving assurance of the friendly disposition of his Government, and their readiness in the event of the appointment of a new Minister, to adjust all the matters of complaint which had been preferred against them, conformably to the Laws of Nations. Mr Clay has requested him before he sends the note definitively to let him see the draught of it; to which he agreed— Mr Clay said he had also in preparation, Instructions to H. Wheaton as Chargé d’Affaires to Denmark— There came about five this afternoon a person named Thomas a Messenger to the Executive Council of Maryland with a demand from the Governor of the State, for the delivery up of a person named Simms, indicted there by a Grand-Jury for horse-stealing— Simms has already been apprehended, and lodged in jail here. The messenger wished to be dispatched immediately; but I informed him the order to the Marshal to deliver up the mare must be issued from the Department of State, and directed him to call for it there to-morrow Morning. There was a large party this Evening at Mr Clay’s, attended by Mary Roberdeau and the younger part of our family—
30. IV: Sun rose 4:41— Swam from the boat ten minutes— Garden

I planted in the garden 35 red cherry stones and 18 black hearts; and observing in the middle alley four shoots of suckers, about two inches above ground from a Plum tree ten feet distant, I made Ouseley spade them up, sever the root from which they grew, and set them out at the North-eastern corner of my eastern bed— I read in Alphonse de Beauchamp’s History of Brazil, an Account of the Trees and plants that grow in that Country—a few pages of Du Hamel’s Physique des Arbres a few in the Treatise on planting, and a few of Hilhouse on the Olive in Michaux. Mr Turner the Collector of Georgetown came and introduced a Mr Latcham, of Lancaster, Pennsylvania; a visit of curiosity— Wyer came to entertain me with his conversation— Dr Watkins came with the copy of the Letter from J. Binns to the Postmaster General, and one from Binns asking him to open it— The Letter to the Postmaster General was a mere statement of facts of the assault and battery committed on Binns by R. Bache. Watkins shewed me also Letters from D. Trimble, of Kentucky, and D. M’Arthur and W. M’lean, members of the 18th. Congress from Ohio— With Trimble’s was a pamphlet published by his opponent at the election for Congress, full of all the Slander upon me that he has been able to collect. The Letters from M’Arthur and W. M’Lean, are in refutation of another Slander; circulated by General Jackson himself. While Watkins was with me, Mr M’lean the Postmaster General came in, and Watkins went away. Mr M’lean shewed me several Letters concerning the competition for the office of Postmaster at Newport R.I between Mr Cranston and Mr Mason— He thought the preponderance was in favour of Cranston; in which opinion I concurred. Mr M’lean also shewed me Binn’s Letter to him, of which Dr Watkins had the copy. He still thought the conduct of Bache, was not of a nature to be officially noticed by him. I thought it might deserve further consideration— As an outrage committed by an Officer of the U.S. upon a Citizen for the exercise of the freedom of the press under the responsibility of his name, and upon a magistrate in the execution of his Office, as an Alderman, under the authority of the State— But as the civil tribunals of Pennsylvania, have taken cognizance of the case and Bache has been bound over, to be amenable to presentment by a Grand-Jury, I agreed that it would be proper to defer any decision upon what it may be proper to do here, till after the adjudication of the case in the State Court. Mr Rush had an answer from Mr Jones the Collector at Philadelphia, to his Letter of last Saturday, concerning the Delaware and Chesapeake Canal. Mr Jones is not a Stockholder in the Canal, and therefore according to Mr Rush’s construction of the Law cannot act as proxy to the Secretary of the Treasury at the Election of Directors— But he recommends a Mr S. Wetherell for that trust; a person of very respectable character— Mr Jones gives in a private Letter some information respecting the progress of the works and prospects of the Canal, which are far from encouraging— Mr Rush is to send immediately the proxy to Mr Wetherell, and as the choice of Directors is to be made next Monday he must have a discretionary authority to vote for whom he shall judge best— He is however to be advised in a private Letter of the existing complaints of mismanagement by the present Directors, and requested to act accordingly— Dr Todsen came to say he was informed a vacancy had occurred of a Clerkship in the War Department—and to solicit my aid that he might obtain it. I referred him to the Secretary of War— Mr Clay was here, with the Note from Mr Rebello, urging the appointment of a Minister to Brazil, and promising in that event a fair adjustment of our complaints— I thought the note might be accepted, with some remarks upon two or three passages in it— Mr Clay sent me in the evening the draught of a reply to it. Mrs Adams, with Mary Roberdeau, and Mary Hellen accompanied by Coll Roberdeau and my Son Charles made an excursion this day to Fort Warburton, where they were received by Coll W. B. Armistead— They came home to a late dinner
31. IV— Walk to the Slashes— Garden walk. Sun rose veiled.

Mr Anderson the Comptroller introduced a young man named Wallace, from Virginia, who has been attending the Law School, of the Chancellor St. George Tucker at Winchester. General Parker came to give me a further explanation upon the subject of his claims for double rations and other allowances in Settlement of his accounts with the United States as Adjutant and Inspector General— He had however nothing new to say— His case is hard, and yet one which I must leave it to the judicial tribunals to decide— Mr Matthews the Clergyman of the Roman Catholic Church, and Mr Weightman the Mayor of the City came as a Committee from the Proprietors of the Washington Library to say that they were desirous of erecting a small brick building in which to keep their Books, and to enquire if I could appropriate to their use a small portion of the public Land in the City for that purpose— I assured them of my disposition to gratify the wish of the Society, as much as might be in my power and took their proposal for Consideration; but expressed doubts with respect to the legal authority of the President thus to dispose of the public land— They mentioned two cases somewhat similar in which former Presidents had partially exercised this authority. Mr Jefferson who had declined giving the land, but had authorised the Commissioners or Superintendent to sell the land for a trifling and merely nominal sum; and Mr Monroe who had authorised public land to be taken, upon condition that it should be restored whenever demanded— I promised to see the Commissioner of the Public buildings and to give them an answer shortly— Mr Clay spoke of the Note received from Mr Rebello the Brazilian, and of his answer— Mr Rush had sundry papers relating to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, and read me the draught of his Power, Instructions and private Letter, to Mr Wetherell who is to be his proxy to vote for Directors at the election next Monday— He read also the papers relating to a claim of the Brothers Baring, for a commission of 1 1/2 per Cent Commission, upon the purchase of certain Louisiana loan-stock—in 1818. which he thought just and reasonable. A. H. Hamilton some time Collector at Pensacola, from which place he was dismissed brought me a Letter a bundle of papers and a book which he requested me to read, believing they would entirely satisfy me that he was unjustly displaced, and hoping that I would in that case give him another appointment— William Lee came to take back a Letter from G. Blake at Philadelphia, announcing the continued convalescence of E. H. Mills, with renewed solicitation for him of an appointment abroad, for the entire recovery of his health— Judge Chase called only to pay a friendly visit— After dinner I rode with John in his Gig round through the woods.

Day— differs little from that of the last Month; excepting in two varieties of my mornings exercise— One by an occasional bath in the Potowmack, and ten minutes swimming; the other, by passing an hour and sometimes two in the Garden— Although my last Autumn’s plantings have not yet appeared, I have determined this year to repeat and multiply the experiments— The inconvenience that I now suffer is that it absorbs too large a portion of my time— The garden stroll added to the walk wastes the hours till breakfast, and then the books waste an hour or two more. Yet my reading is desultory and confused— Then my visitors an incessant stream, with Letters, despatches and Newspapers, keep me in constant employment, from the breakfast morning hour of nine till the Evening dinner hour of five— From seven or eight, until ten I have yet continued to write, for the Summer heat has not definitively set in— But my writing on the Colonial trade question flags, and other business gets in arrear— Loudon’s Encyclopaedia’s of gardening and of Agriculture— Du Hamel du Monceau’s Treatises upon Trees. Michaux’s North American Silva, and two or three other Books upon Botany have amused some portion of my time— My health has still been very indifferent, but has within the last fortnight become more promising—
